7e2617a66594d8932013a5022b280c45 (16:49): and there are differences between atk/at-spi, Iaccessible2, Universal Access, UI Automation, etc.
7e2617a66594d8932013a5022b280c45 (16:50): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: it is microsoft's new API for vista
7e2617a66594d8932013a5022b280c45 (16:50): what happened is they gave up on msaa
7e2617a66594d8932013a5022b280c45 (16:50): which was a problem, because people had lots of msaa code in apps and assistive tech
7e2617a66594d8932013a5022b280c45 (16:50): and UIA was just an API for  managed code
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (16:50): yeah, i'm not sure how to spec it in a sane way. in order to test it you probably need an accessibility api debugger...
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (16:51): oh. I wasn't up to speed on MS doing something other than MSAA
7e2617a66594d8932013a5022b280c45 (16:51): so IBM worked with the community to build IAccessible2, which are API extensions to MSAA and matches closely with ATK/AT-SPI on Linux
7e2617a66594d8932013a5022b280c45 (16:51): I was part of that effort
7e2617a66594d8932013a5022b280c45 (16:51): it's what we're using in FIrefox now
7e2617a66594d8932013a5022b280c45 (16:51): because it can build on msaa support and yet is very similar to ATK, you can leverage a lot of existing code and get cross platform a11y
7e2617a66594d8932013a5022b280c45 (16:52): the AT vendors had a lot less work to implement support for it, because they get to build on top of exisiting support for MSAA
7e2617a66594d8932013a5022b280c45 (16:52): 73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46: http://developer.mozilla.org/en/docs/ARIA_to_API_mapping
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (16:52): 7e2617a66594d8932013a5022b280c45: is Universal Access a good match?
73eaf221abca1b8244e34b0b9e76ac46 (16:53): 7e2617a66594d8932013a5022b280c45: the proposal references that :)

7e2617a66594d8932013a5022b280c45 (16:53): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: universal access is cool because it just name value pairs. It's loosely spec'd which honestly is an advantage in this space, because you don't have to rev a whole lot of binary software in lock step to get new features in
7e2617a66594d8932013a5022b280c45 (16:53): you can just expose some new a11y property
7e2617a66594d8932013a5022b280c45 (16:53): and then ask ATs to support
7e2617a66594d8932013a5022b280c45 (16:54): But with binary APIs, adding new features is a total nightmare
7e2617a66594d8932013a5022b280c45 (16:54): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: and the values in the name value pairs don't have to be strings, it can be a hash table for example
7e2617a66594d8932013a5022b280c45 (16:54): so you can send any event data you want, for example, it's great
7e2617a66594d8932013a5022b280c45 (16:55): the big disadvantage is that there is really only one (closed) screen reader supporting it, which is owned by the platform vendors
7e2617a66594d8932013a5022b280c45 (16:55): so it is harder to influence them if you need new features, like accessible live regions or drag and drop, or whatever

7e2617a66594d8932013a5022b280c45 (16:55): but, to answer your question, the name/value pairs Apple is using most likely fit well enough, but we only have stub support for UA in Mozilla so I can't say what the major integration issues will be yet
